text: this is get eaten for the New York Times
there's really no excuse for not using
good grammar when you're writing or
speaking especially when there are a
host of apps like practice English
grammar
available on the App Store's this
particular app is available for both iOS
and Android and is free and the lessons
it contains cover all the usual
grammatical things you might want to
know lessons are broken down into
different modules and the home screen
gives you a graphical display of how far
you are through each module inside each
module there are sections for learning
about different grammatical tricks
displayed in the form of digital
flashcards with explanations on the back
earned a section for testing your
knowledge the professional-looking
minimalist design of each of these
sections may sometimes feel a little too
Spartan as in lacking the element of fun
that sometimes makes learning easier the
other downside to this app is that while
the basic lessons are free for higher
levels you have to pay one dollar for
each lesson for a slightly more
lighthearted alternative for this app
check out learn English grammar from the
British Council this app is also free
for both iOS and Android and has a
similar kind of minimalist look in some
ways it's also broken into learning and
testing sections but I find the gently
game-like quizzes you have to do in the
testing section much more fun again
while the core sections of this app are
free for higher-level lessons you have
to pay one dollar for each pack make
sure you get the US grammar version of
this app - unless you're interested in
learning the grammar rules in the UK
version and lastly there's grammar up
which is also free on iOS and Android
below it will cost you $5 for all
content this grammar learning app is
slightly more graphical and slightly
more relaxed than the other two and has
some handy feedback graphs that might
help you understand where you tend to
slip up on good grammar and that's it
from a hopefully grammatically correct
me see you next week
Oh
